newsitem.title: ITALY: U.S. government food aid reaches N Korea.
newsitem.headline: U.S. government food aid reaches N Korea.

text.p: A consignment of food aid donated by the U.S. government has arrived in North Korea in response to a U.N. World Food Programme appeal to help the country avoid famine, the WFP said on Thursday.

The Rome-based agency said the U.S. vessel Galveston Bay, chartered by the WFP, had docked at the port of Nampo, southwest of the capital Pyongyang, on Wednesday with 8,500 tonnes of maize and 4,992 tonnes of corn soya blend.
Unloading began on Thursday, a WFP statement said.
"WFP will monitor the discharge of the Galveston Bay's cargo and its distribution to 2.6 million children aged six and younger at kindergartens and nurseries," the statement said.
It said a second vessel with canned meat and around 16,000 tonnes of food grains, some 13,500 tonnes of it from the U.S. government, was due to arrive at Nampo on May 19.

The agency said both shipments were in response to a joint appeal from the WFP and the U.N. Food and Agriculture Organisation on April 2 for $95.5 million in emergency assistance for communist North Korea.
WFP executive director Catherine Bertini followed up in late April with a fresh appeal for government-to-government aid to North Korea, which was hit by destructive floods in 1995 and 1996.

The WFP has so far this year appealed for 200,000 tonnes of food for North Korea, or about $95 million. About $38.6 million of this has been raised. The United States has pledged $25 million and South Korea $6 million.
